answers.answer: Take a couple of deep breaths and relax. You cannot contact HIV from a eating utensil used by an HIV + person.Cotton wool spots are caused most commonly by diabetes and hypertension and in younger people by some blood and autoimmune diseases. Heavy smoking in a young peerson and "shooting up" with heroin like drugs can be a cause. They can occur in healthy persons "for no good reason" they do not effect vision and eventually go away.Your retina specialist hopefully will give you good results on all your tests.

Thanks, doc.  I have been so stressed over this!!!  The internet could really misinform, I suppose.  I am not a heavy smoker by any means, I was a  "light/mod smoker" but quit dec 06.  Anyway, results should be in this week, thanks again!
Good luck. Don't start smoking again. Bad for your eyes: cataracts, macular degeneration, blood vessel clots, poor night vision.JCH MD

So, this is just a coincidence, then?  The fact that I have such an uncommon health issue, three weeks after the event where I ate the contaminated food, smothered by her fork?  I feel this is too much a coincidence, and I am so scared.  I even think I have swollen lymph nodes now, causing more and more fear!
At this point I can't help you deal with your anxiety any more. Discuss with your personal physician.JCH MD
I received my 30 day hiv home access test result-negative.  Since there was little, or no risk to begin with, I assume I am clear, right?-
If it were me that's what I would assume.JCH MD

question: Hi,About 5 days ago, I began noticing a semi circle when my eye is closed and occasionally a flash.  Upon examination by opthamlomologist, he noticed a cotton wool spot in my left eye.  He referred me to a retinal specialist.  Retinal specialist did not seem worried, and said the tests look ok, but referred me for a bunch of blood tests just in case.  BTW, I am 24 year old female, which is why the doctor referred me to a specialist, since this is apparently uncommon for someone my age.  In researching this to death, I saw that HIV is also a cause.  I am married and monogomous and last hiv test was 9-06 negative.  About a month ago, I believe I ate food that was contaminated with an HIV pos person's fork. Could this be a symptom from this event?  Or do you believe the cotton wool spot is idiopathic, considering i do not have diabetes or high blood pressure.   I am scareed, awaiting test results.Thanks
title: Cotton Wool Spot
